reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can not recommend this game to anyone, especially through steam.
It is another mobile facebook browser game port to steam.

Early Access???  I do not know how they can claim it is an early access game.  The game has been on Facebook for 5 years now.

If you do not want to read the whole reveiw here is the #1 game breaking killer for me.
Afer 99 days the world totally resets.
You lose your hero, you lose your town, you lose your armies, you lose your items.

Now if that one thing does not do it for you then we will get into the obvious pay to win model found here.
You can spend real money to buy more resources.
You can spend real money to speed up building time.
You can spend real money to speed up training time.
You can spend real money to buy weapons and armor for your hero.
You can spend real money to buy command points, the currency that allows you to raid things in game, otherwise you get 1 per hour why you wait and watch your buildings grow.

You can raid other players cities but you can not take them over??

Apparently the goal of the game is for an alliance to build something as a team to win??

So some other reviews compared this to Lords of Ultima, well only in the basic bare bones sense.
It is more like Travian where the higher levels raid the lower levels 5 minutes after the new player protection wears off in 5 days.  There is no bunker, so when you get raided you will lose 100% of all your resources.

Some good things for a browser game, forge, magic spells, basic research.
However, since you are coming in through steam you can not have 4 tabs open and play something else while you wait, or stream movies through Hulu or Netflix.  No, all you can do is have this one game open and wait and wait and wait or spend or spend or spend and watch everything go away in 99 days.

So I started the game, it was on day 11 so I have a few days to keep playing it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFirst of all, this game isn't very deep and it's actually rather boring. For the first few days of this you may have fun. You might even figure out how to play on other worlds and harvest and sell goods for gems (premium currency) which you can then use on your main account. However, even after finding out that this game is only pay2win-for-the-ignorant I'm still left with this feeling that this game doesn't have enough to keep me wanting to come back. The battles last about a minute, there are no graphics (just a clock). There is an arena, joy! But the Arena fights are over and decided, calculated by some algorithm in a matter of miliseconds (literally after you choose your opponent, it's over). I understand, there are many games like these. But these games belong in browsers, for casual gamers and not on steam for people that actually know what a real strategy, or an mmorts feels like. This is just bubblegum. You'll spit it out too. Don't say I didn't warn you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of downvotes on this game, but I give it an upvote for very specific reasons.

Pros:
The microtransactions are NOT needed in this game. You can have just as much fun playing as without paying for it.
The community will talk to you and shoot you advice. It's nice to see such friendliness in a cut throat style game.
There are a lot of ways of leveling up your hero and mistakes only make for a better gameplay.
The game resets after a certain amount of days and this is so you can experience the game again differently. It allows people to level up and to try a new path.
I think they nailed the RTS system down and none of the requirements are too hefty.


Cons:
I think the only complaint is the higher levels can attack whoever they want. It should be implemented that only 4 levels above you can attack. I lost all my troops and re sources (though the game gave me a freebee diplomacy).

IF YOU LIKE AN RTS WITH A TWIST, THIS ONE IS FOR YOU. I would higggggggggghhhhhhhhhllllllllyyyyyyyyy recommend it to anyone who enjoys a challenge.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr:  It's an idling game with a few clever ideas implemented in the worst way


Emporea is an idling game where you can join Alliances(guilds/clans/teams) and build up a city and army to raid monster camps and propsper - or attack players and win.

On the core level, it's actually pretty robust for an idling game - there's a fair number of unit types and progress and the way you can trade between allies is intuitive and useful since the various races require different combinations of resources to be effective.  My Dwarven army was virtually always out of Stone or Iron, but Stone moreso since buildings needed it more.  However, I always had a gross abundance of Wood - and I would trade Wood for Stone with a teammate and this was cool.

It has some Facebook style BS I hate where you have to ask random friends for random items as well as give those random items away (without it reducing your quantity) which is also 90% of the gameplay for WEBKINZ, but because it's only used for Alchemy in this game, which has limited utility, it balances out.

Now, this is where things turn south...  After a few days of upgrades you'll notice that some of the top clans are insurmountably better than everyone else combined.  This is because, ugh, PAY 2 WIN.

Now, ok - Pay2Win is something people just have to accept in this style of game, but it conflicts with another core element...  individual servers reset at the end of every season, which is relatively short (3 months);  Similar to NukeZone.   Both ideas work on their own, but the moment you combine them ANY notion of fair competition flies out the window.  You can have either/or, but not BOTH.

You don't have to Pay2Win, after all - it's not like you NEED to win, it's just a game right?  Well, this brings up the next point - the reseting servers.  The Pay4Play item in this game is called Gems, and like most Freemium games you can find a few of them naturally while playing.  The downside is... GEMS PROGRESS ACROSS SERVERS!!  So now not only can you Pay2Win if you wanted, but you can level up an alt to farm items for your closed realm - completely defeating the purpose of limited servers.

However, ok - maybe you don't care about competition at all... you're just here for the sweet Achievement Score on AStats, well - you're good to go, you can get almost all of them from playing one server of each race concurrently.  If you are very active, the SMALLEST idling period is 5~6 minutes - to raid a portal for a token reward, it's easy to switch realms in this time period and be set for life, maybe even getting GEMs you can use on your other characters.  But you'll NEVER get the victory achievement...  even if you dump tens of THOUSANDS of dollars on the game, you'd have to have an entire alliance doing the same, while also all feeding their own meta progress via alternate servers.  You can't actually win, not ever.


On the other hand, if you simply don't care about winning and just like idling games - there's a lot to do in this game, so it's certainly worth a try, just don't get mad (like me) when you finally cash in 50 quest items only to see the number 1 player cashed in 100'000 of them.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEven though the game play is wonderful, the people are friendly, and the classes are great... there are HUGE downfalls to this game. I wouldn't recommend it if you want to go from Top of the Dog Pile to bottom within a mere day because it resets the entire world, progress, class, race, and everything else every 3 months. (HORRIBLE FEATURE.) Plus, you can not add anyone to your friends list unless it's through Facebook? Really? Tips: Let someone choose their race, name, and KEEP their Empire without losing 3 months of their life just to GRIND to do it all over again. If you want a grindy game, go buy a JRPG. I'm sorry, but I will not be reinstalling this game until the reset" feature is gone and you can at least add your friends so they don't know your "real" name.. Who knows who these people may be? You don't know! I loved the game
date: but the deal breaker were those two things. I'm actually very sorry to see this game go from my Games List... If you want to keep grinding then this game is for you... But I wouldn't waste my time on it."

Gameplay itself is quite decent. It's a browser-based MMORTS.

However, it's extremely P2W.
As an old veteran in Tribalwars, I used to love sending out my army to raid settlements.
First thing I noticed in this game, is that raiding also works well, however your moves are limited.
1 attack point per hour, stacks up till 20. Unless... money money money.
You can buy attack points for real money.

The more you buy, the more you can raid, the more you earn resources.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The pay to win waiting game.

Very basic browser game. Build some buildings in your city. Raid for resources. Level up your hero. Upgrade town. Upgrade army. Grind for gear. Grind for chrystals. Sounds nice right? Except you have to wait a long time before you can actually do anything.

You get 1 attack per hour, which means you can attack 1 enemy each hour. Want more? Buy gems. You can build / upgrade 2 buildings at the same time. Want more? Buy gems. Guess what, you can buy gems with real money.

Decent game to play on your phone for 5 minute every couple of hours. Not so decent to play behind your pc.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh man where do I even begin with this game. (looooong history)

I used to play it on bigpoint, when it was version 2. Then i played version 3 somewhere and today the version 4 is even better and well-balanced. (v2 undead was OP!)

10hours/day was my daily dose, now as recovered addict 5 is enough.

So the game itself is played on servers that have fixed time of ending and every 2 weeks starts a new one. Devs have implemented speed-up mechanic for new comers, so when you even start a server late with buffs you can easily catchup with the rest of players. During the world every 2 weeks are special events with unique units so the gameplay doesnt get repetitive. Sometimes there is a special world that has different rules than the other ones.

Even when the game is freemium the endgame is more about politics and tactics than money spent.

Devs are very responsive and friendly (thumbsup)

the game is still in beta, so bugs&glitches are occasional but after reporting to devs. They are fixed either instantly or in some next update (game gets updated regularly every 2 weeks).

Also you can play it on android or apple device!
--------------------------------------------------------

tl;dr if you like oldschool mmo rpg-strategic mid-core games this one is for you definitely 11/10
